text: the exhibition is curated by Martin Parr
who is undoubtedly Britain's best-known
chronicler of modern life there are
artists of photographers that have never
settled in Britain so these are artists
that have travelled through here and so
we could have chosen a great many other
photographers but these we felt charted
as kind of history of Britain from the
30s to the present day and portrayed a
very vibrant portrait of modern Britain
some of these pictures are from earlier
from the 1930s
Edith Tudor heart she had a very
particular social political agenda she
was a committed communist and she
photographed a lot of the children's
plight she wanted to kind of highlight
poverty the well-being of children
homelessness and so on in the capital
and beyond
tell us about Ramon Thibodeau he was
very well versed in in photographing in
conflict zones in northern Africa but in
1980 he was commissioned by the Sunday
Times Magazine to travel to Glasgow and
he portrayed a picture of Glasgow that
was fairly bleak and grim it's infused
with absolute kind of despair and the
kind of backdrop of kind of socio
economic decline that had been happening
for decades in Glasgow and he managed to
capture it and it's kind of evocative
and surreal and beauty and all these
stories you want to know what's gone on
beyond the kind of picture frame let's
turn to another photographer Japanese
this time Akihiko Okamura and his
coverage of Londonderry Derry and the
Battle of the box work yeah he spent 10
years documenting and it's kind of very
lyrical poignant melancholic color war
photography and it's more photography
will so used to seeing images of war
that are kind of dramatized and have
really charged and these are inflected
with a kind of Airy lyricism of beauty
kind of incidental everyday in formal
snapshots and they feel very really
quite different but nonetheless very
charged and showing a side of the
conflict that you know here in Britain
we don't tend to want to see or remember
you
